Message:
Validation of profile photos, and resizing them to thumbnails

This verifies the initial bytes of the file match the magic bytes of pngs, jpegs, gifs or bmps, and constructs a tightly-constrained call to imagemagick's `convert` to downsize the image to a jpeg of at most 200x300 pixels and at most 40kb in file-size.  If this succeeds, the initial uploaded file is deleted and the user's profile is updated to the thumbnail.  This helps speed up roster pages (which show students' thumbnails on popover) and the course facebook page (which shows everyone in the course) that have to download a lot of images...

Name: Ben Lerner
Message:
Initial implementation of codereview assignments.  This is an interim
commit; many things are still broken.

- A Codereview assignment can either be a Peer review or a Self
  review.  Peer reviews can require that student review multiple
  submissions; self reviews obviously only require one

- A Codereview assignment can specify a grade threshold below which
  reviews will not be shown to the reviewees. (This helps avoid
  showing crappy or needlessly cruel reviews to students.)

- A Codereview submission creates a Grade for itself, which is the
  grade that course staff gives to the review itself.

- A Codereview submission also creates ReviewFeedbacks, one per
  submission that was reviewed, which point back to the Grade and
  which contain the graded score for this one review alone (i.e.,
  ignoring the others)

- Any submission (but typically only Files submissions) can have a
  collection of ReviewFeedbacks associated with it, which will only be
  shown if they're above the grading threshold and published (or if
  the current user is staff)

- A reviewee student can see the fact that their code has been
  reviewed, and will either be informed that the review is not yet
  unavailable, be informed that it is being withheld because it is too
  low quality, or be given a link to see the review.

- A reviewee student can see the review for their submission, but
  cannot see the grade (or staff feedback) their reviewer received.

- Reviews do not have any impact on the grade of the reviewee.

- Codereview submissions are much like Questions submissions, except
  with one additional level of indirection: the answers are chunked by
  the id of the underlying submission being reviewed.  (This ensures
  that we associate the right responses to the right submissions;
  ordering of reviews is not guaranteed or needed.)

- Questions submissions are totally broken in this commit, now.
  (Oddly, and worryingly, all tests still pass... this is more due to
  a lack of tests than a high quality of code.)

- The Interlocks table is intended to ensure various ordering
  constraints on assignments.  The model is present but this table is
  not yet used by any controllers.

- Existing Questions assignments with non-nil related assignments will
  be converted to Codereview self-review assignments.  Questions
  assignments will no longer ever have related assignments, and will
  solely be quizzes/questionnaires.  This is not yet implemented.

Miscellaneous:

- The schema for professors to supply rubrics to questions has been
  enhanced to allow giving a hint message to the graders and a separate
  feedback message to students.

- Various coding improvments (lots of conditional cruft is replaced by
  calls to &.dig(...), more functionality moved into models or
  helpers)

- Codemirror has been removed from the Gemfile.  Instead, it is now
  installed via npm, which allows us to track npm packages more
  readily (they update more frequently than the -rails equivalent gems
  do).  Likewise the pyret-mode has been removed from
  app/assets/javascript, and is now an npm mode.

Apparently, the genius Powers That Be do not mandate that CRNs are globally unique -- they're only unique within an academic year.  This affects

* Sections (schema is unique on crn, after_save is probably not needed now)
* RegistrationSection (belongs_to section by way of crn)
* RegRequest (which looks up Sections by way of crn without checking for Courses, and creates new RegRequestSections using crns instead of ids)
* RegRequestSection (belongs_to section by way of crn)
* Course (students_with_section uses crn instead of id)
* CoursesController (definition of students_by_section uses section_id where it means crn)

and various views that filter on crns.  This is a somewhat risky commit, since it affects the primary/foreign keys of lots of records, but hopefully I've caught all the important connections.

Message:
Support for extra credit assignments and extra credit graders.  Fixes #21.

* Extra credit assignments are excluded from the computation of available and
  total_points in a course, and so are excluded from the computation of current
  grade estimates' denominators.  They are also excluded from the assignment-weight
  page, and separated into their own category.
* Extra credit graders are excluded from the computation of the maximum points
  available in an assignment, and so are excluded from submissions' grade denominators.
* It is technically possible to have an extra credit graders on an extra credit assignment.
  This would mean that the "maximum grade" for that assignment is lower than the sum of the
  weights of all of its graders, making it that much easier to get a good grade on that
  assignment.  Why you would want to do this, I do not know.
* Most of the work in this commit is UI tweaks to enable editing the extra-credit status
  of graders.

Message:
Client-side fix for race condition causing duplicated comments:

Dynamically creating comments gives them a bogus id derived from a timestamp.  The autosave AJAX gets back a dictionary from the server mapping those timestamps to proper comment ids.  Subsequent modifications of those comments will use those correct ids, so they can't be duplicated.  The problem occurs for comments that have not yet received a valid id.  If a grader clicks the submit button while the AJAX autosave request is still in flight, the grade-submission will occur first and save all the comments, and then the AJAX will occur and re-save them (since it doesn't know about the new comment ids), causing duplication.

The fix here is to disable submission while AJAX is pending.

Name: Ben Lerner
Message:
Fix NPE in grader_allocations/index and /edit, in the following scenario:

* Create a team submission for an assignment with a manual grader
* Allocate a grader to that submission, and have the grader enter some comments but not complete the grading
* Split the submission into individual subs
* Try to view or edit the grader allocations for the assignment now

The problem is that manual_grader would guess that a reasonable grader for the new subs exists, but because grading isn't finished, this should not be true.  The fix is two-fold: harden the guessing so that it only checks for completed grades (this grade.score.nil? check is now the same in both ManualGrader and index.html, so these stay in sync), and fix the sub-splitting process to migrate any existing grader allocations to the new submissions.

Message:
Fixing #153.  This is a bit subtle:

* Until now, every Grader has either been wholly normal-points or wholly extra-credit-points.  But exams can have e.c. questions as well.
* An appealing solution is to make every Grader have *two* score fields, avail_normal_score and avail_ec_score.  But this doesn't work well: in our current setting, a ManualGrader with normal points can go above its maximum score (to allow for correcting other, overzealous autograders).  But a ManualGrader with e.c. points has a maximum it ought to go to.  If we combined these into a single grader, then we wouldn't know whether to cap the score or not.  (We don't currently cap the score for e.c. either, but there's a TODO saying we should...)
* Instead, we'll allow all Graders to self-report how many points are normal, and how many are extra-credit.  In ManualGraders, these two points should sum to the avail_score, since they're mutually exclusive.  But in ExamGraders, they may both be non-zero, and sum to more than the avail_score.

Fortunately, these scores already worked properly in the Gradesheet export (thanks to fixing #12).  This fix repairs how students see their own scores.

Message:
Fixes https://github.com/CodeGrade/bottlenose/issues/114.  Fixes https://github.com/CodeGrade/bottlenose/issues/13

When a professors messes up the exam rubric, there are (at least) three possible remedies: we might choose to delete all existing scores and try again; we might treat all scores as being scaled proportionately to the new weights; or we might treat the old scores as absolute point values.  Since Bottlenose can't choose among these three options, we present them to the professor, and edit the existing grades accordingly.  Editing the exam rubric will be rejected when:

* The number of questions (or their subparts) changes, and the professor wants to preserve existing entered grades
* The point values have lowered, scores are being treated as absolute points, and some student had a score above that new maximum

It is possible that even more fine grained policies might be possible (e.g. per-question policies), but these seem eminently reasonable and sufficient for now.

Name: Ben Lerner
Message:
Fixing XSS attack, found by Jaden Zhou and Nathan Stein:
The bootstrap-treeview component uses jQuery.append() to add nodes into the treeview, and the content of those nodes are filenames controlled by students.  If a student picked a filename that looked like a script-tag, then jQuery would inject a <script> tag!  The fix is to preemptively replace all such strings with DOM elements whose text content is explicitly set to be those strings -- since we know the content *should* be pure text, we can create these spans very easily.
